Package chess.model

Class ChessGame

java.lang.Object
chess.model.ChessGame
All Implemented Interfaces:
chess.persistence.Codable
public class ChessGame extends Object implements chess.persistence.Codable
A class that manages the lifecycle and state of a single Chess game.

A Chess game involves a Chessboard, and two Player objects. During a game, the two players take turns and make moves. This class manages the lifecycle and states of the Chessboard and host the game between the two players. In addition, this class also manages game-related states and behaviors that are external to the chessboard (e.g. undo/redo, reset, etc.).

This class provides a navigable view of a Chess game, that is, a game can be easily navigated backward/forward in time via a uniform control. The current state of the Chess game is thought of as a composition of transformations with respect to the initial state (setup). Actions like a regular turn, undo, or redo are just nuanced transformations that can be reversed/reproduced. This class merely maintains the relevant transformations and computes the state of the game on the go. For instance, there are three major kinds of transformation,

  • A regular turn (a player making a move): a transformation forward in time, which, upon a move is made, clears all future transformations;
  • An undo (backward action): a transformation backward in time, the inverse transformation of a regular turn or a redo/forward action;
  • A redo (forward action): resembling a regular turn, it is also a transformation forward in time, except that the transformation is determined.
This class also buffers the current state of the game so that the state can be retrieved without re-computation.

In addition to game-related states, this class also manages the following states:

  1. Read-only: when a game is set to read only, no transformation can be applied (no undo/redo, forward/backward, or advance turn);
  2. Pause/Resume: when a game is paused, only forward and backward actions are allowed (no undo/redo or advance turn).
Note that this class does NOT handle the abnormal states of the game in any manner.

      public ChessGame(String name, Chessboard chessboard, Player whitePlayer, Player blackPlayer)
      Constructs a Chess game with a given name, a chessboard, a White player, and a Black player. If name is empty, the default name will be used.
      Parameters:
      name - The name of the game, a non-empty string.
      chessboard - The chessboard of the game.
      whitePlayer - The White player.
      blackPlayer - The Black player.
      Throws:
      NullPointerException - If any of the arguments is null.

    • ChessGame

      public ChessGame(org.json.JSONObject jsonObject)
      Constructs a Chess game from a JSON source containing the following required key-value mappings: 
       {
     "name":"<name>",
     "chessboard":<chessboard>,
     "state":<state>,
     "whitePlayer": <player-1>,
     "blackPlayer": <player-2>,
     "history": [
         ...
     ],
     "future": [
         ...
     ]
 }
      where:
      • <name>: the name of this game;
      • <chessboard>: the associated chessboard encoded as a JSON object;
      • <state>: the state object encoded as a JSON object;
      • <player-1>: the White player encoded as a JSON object;
      • <player-2> the Black player encoded as a JSON object;
      • <history>: a collection of previous transformations encoded as a JSON array of JSON objects;
      • <history>: a collection of next transformations encoded as a JSON array of JSON objects.
      Parameters:
      jsonObject - The source JSONObject from which to decode.
      Throws:
      org.json.JSONException - If any of the required keys is missing or maps to an invalid value type.
      FormatException - Rethrown from any of the following method calls (follow to see details):
      • Chessboard(JSONObject);
      • ChessGame.State.decode(JSONObject);
      • Player.decode(JSONObject);
      • Transformation(JSONObject, Chessboard).
      NullPointerException - If jsonObject is null.

    • hasConcluded

      public boolean hasConcluded()
      Note: This does NOT indicate that the game has ever been concluded before, it merely reflects whether the current state of this game is conclusive.
      Returns:
      A boolean value indicating whether the current state of this game is conclusive.

    • hasNextTurn

      public boolean hasNextTurn()
      This method returns the effective negation of the method hasConcluded(). A game has next turn if and only if the game has not concluded, i.e. one of the players can still make a move. By entailment, if this method evaluates to false, then the method hasForward() also evaluates to false, but not its inverse or converse. Use this method to decide whether the method nextTurn() can be called.
      Returns:
      A boolean value indicating whether this game can be advanced by one of its player making a move.

      public boolean isPaused()
      Returns:

      public boolean isInspectionOnly()
      The game may not proceed as normal if it has been paused or set to read-only mode.
      Returns:
      A boolean value indicating whether this game can only be inspected.

    • getStateDescription

      public String getStateDescription()
      Returns:
      A state description of this game.

    • canUndo

      public boolean canUndo()
      This game can be undone if and only if:
      • the game is not in inspection mode (paused or read-only);
      • the player to move is not an agent or the current state is conclusive;
      • the game has previous record of transformations.
      In the case of the game state being conclusive, allowing undo enables the final player (whether an agent or human) to retract the last move and go for an alternative move.
      Returns:
      A boolean value indicating whether this game can be undone.

    • canRedo

      public boolean canRedo()
      This game can be redone if and only if:
      • the game is not in inspection mode (paused or read-only);
      • the current state is inconclusive;
      • the player to move is not an agent;
      • the game has record of future transformations.
      Returns:
      A boolean value indicating whether this game can be redone.

    • canReset

      public boolean canReset()
      This game can be reset if and only if it has been transformed, i.e. this game has recorded transformations either in the past or future.
      Returns:
      A boolean value indicating whether this game can be reset.

    • hasBackward

      public boolean hasBackward(int turns)
      This game can be navigated backward N turns if and only if it has >= N recorded transformations in the past, for some positive integer N.
      Parameters:
      turns - The number of turns as a positive integer.
      Returns:
      A boolean value indicating whether this game can be navigated backward N turns, for some positive integer N.
      Throws:
      IllegalArgumentException - If turns <= 0.

    • hasBackward

      public boolean hasBackward()
      Returns:
      A boolean value indicating whether this game can be navigated backward for one turn.

    • hasForward

      public boolean hasForward(int turns)
      This game can be navigated forward N turns if and only if it has >= N recorded transformations in the future, for some positive integer N.
      Parameters:
      turns - The number of turns as a positive integer.
      Returns:
      A boolean value indicating whether this game can be navigated forward N turns, for some positive integer N.
      Throws:
      IllegalArgumentException - If turns <= 0.

    • hasForward

      public boolean hasForward()
      Returns:
      A boolean value indicating whether this game can be navigated forward for one turn.

    • nextTurn

      public void nextTurn() throws GameException
      Advances this game to the next turn. This method calls the current player's Player.getPlayerMove(Chessboard) method with a copy of the associated chessboard to obtain this player's move. After which, the retrieved move is validated and executed. In the case of a human player, this method should be preceded by an appropriate call to HumanPlayer.registerNextMove(Position, Position). Ideally, this method should be called on its own thread (a thread separate from the main application thread) to prevent UI unresponsiveness since this method could be potentially time-consuming (depending on the agent) in which case letting it block the thread may not desirable.
      Throws:
      IllegalOperation - If one or more of the following scenarios occur, i.e. this game:
      1. is in inspection mode (paused or read-only);
      2. has no next turn;
      3. is paused halfway.
      IllegalMove - If the move retrieved from the current player is illegal.
      GameException
      See Also:
      • Player.getPlayerMove(Chessboard)

    • undo

      public void undo()
      Initiated by the current player, this method undoes an appropriate number of turns.
      Throws:
      IllegalOperation - If this game cannot be undone.
      See Also:
      • canUndo()

    • undoOrBackward

      public void undoOrBackward()
      Based on whether this game is in inspection mode, this method performs the appropriate backward-navigation action.

    • backward

      public void backward(int turns)
      Backward-navigates this game N turns for some positive integer N. This is done by repeatedly applying inverse transformations.

      Throws:
      IllegalOperation - If this game cannot be backward-navigated N turns.
